metadata.case_name: Thomcos Bank Ltd. v. N.S. Anirudhan

facts.text: Bank agreed to allow an overdraft to defendant No. 1 (Shankaran/Sankaran/V. Sankaran) for Rs. 20,000/-
Appellant (N.S. Anirudhan) gave a surety bond/letter of guarantee for the repayment of Rs. 25,000/-
Principal debtor (Sankaran) made alteration in the document by reducing the figure from Rs. 25,000/- to Rs. 20,000/-

Appellant claimed he stood surety originally for Rs. 5,000/- which was altered to Rs. 20,000/-, but this case was disbelieved by trial court and High Court; found originally Rs. 25,000/- altered to Rs. 20,000/-
Overdraft arrangement commenced on February 24, 1947, when Sankaran executed a promissory note for Rs. 20,000/- in favour of the Bank

Letter of guarantee typed by Bank with blanks; handed to Sankaran; brought back in May 1947 with Rs. 25,000/- filled; Bank not prepared to advance more than Rs. 20,000/-, returned to Sankaran who altered it to Rs. 20,000/-
Suit filed by Bank against Sankaran (principal debtor) and Anirudhan (guarantor); decreed against Sankaran by trial court, no appeal; against Anirudhan dismissed by trial court
Kerala High Court in Appeal Suit No. 19 of 1956, judgment dated September 30, 1957, decreed against appellant relying on s. 87 Negotiable Instruments Act
Alterations in Exhibit C (letter of guarantee): figure 5 in Rs. 25,000/- altered to 0, word 'five' in 'Rupees twenty five thousand' struck out
No prior oral agreement between Bank and Anirudhan found by High Court

legal_issues.text: Whether the alteration of the letter of guarantee from Rs. 25,000/- to Rs. 20,000/- by the principal debtor constitutes a material alteration that avoids the contract and discharges the surety
Whether the alteration carries out the common intention of the parties or was a mistake, making it immaterial
Whether the principal debtor was acting as agent of the guarantor, estopping the guarantor from pleading material alteration

petitioner_arguments.text: Any change of figure was a material alteration resulting in avoidance of the contract, even if advantageous to the obligor; unauthorised material alteration avoids contract; appellant never assented to altered obligation or original as not accepted by creditor
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Halsbury's Laws of England, 3rd Edn., Vol. 8, para 301, p. 176

petitioner_arguments.text: Originally guaranteed Rs. 5,000/- altered to Rs. 20,000/- without consent, material alteration absolves liability

respondent_arguments.text: Alteration not material as it reduced limit of liability from Rs. 25,000/- to Rs. 20,000/-, not to prejudice of surety; alteration by principal debtor who was agent of guarantor as document handed to him for delivery to Bank
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Williston on Contracts, Vol. VI, para 1914; Halsbury's Laws of England

respondent_arguments.text: Alteration carries out common intention for overdraft of Rs. 20,000/-; Rs. 25,000/- was mistake
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 87 Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881; Halsbury's Laws of England, 3rd edn., vol. 11, p. 370

court_reasoning.text: Document altered by principal debtor acting as agent of guarantor (appellant handed deed to debtor for Bank); avoidance by material alteration inapplicable as not altered in possession of promisee
court_reasoning.key_observation: Principal debtor acting for appellant estops plea of want of authority

court_reasoning.text: No evidence of mistake in writing Rs. 25,000/-; intention must be apparent on face of deed at execution; no prior agreement proved; alteration not to carry out intention
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court relied on conjecture; s.87 N.I. Act principle inapplicable

court_reasoning.text: Even if alteration immaterial (beneficial), original document not accepted by Bank (no contract for Rs.25,000/-); suit on Rs.20,000/- fails as altered without consent and original not basis of suit
court_reasoning.key_observation: Altered document not binding; unaltered proves no contract sued upon

court_reasoning.text: Reduction from Rs.25,000/- to Rs.20,000/- not material alteration; beneficial to surety; principal debtor had authority to amend offer (reduce amount); estoppel as held out as agent
court_reasoning.key_observation: Document continues to represent intention to guarantee up to Rs.25,000/- which includes Rs.20,000/-; surety liability strictissimi juris but unsubstantial beneficial alterations do not discharge

holdings.text: Unauthorised material alteration by principal debtor acting as agent of guarantor does not avoid contract
Alteration reducing liability is not material and does not discharge surety if beneficial and unsubstantial
No discharge where alteration by co-executant (debtor) reduces liability for both

precedents_cited.relevance: Principle applies to instruments under hand; alteration carrying out intention on face
Intention at execution; correction of mistake

precedents_cited.case_name: Ananda Mohan Saha v. Ananda Chandra Naha
precedents_cited.relevance: Intention obvious on document; alteration to per cent
Surety bound to letter; alteration ends obligation - but not if unsubstantial/beneficial
Unsubstantial or beneficial alterations do not discharge surety

precedents_cited.case_name: Ward v. National Bank of New Zealand Ltd.

precedents_cited.relevance: Strict rule on alterations tempered; not if immaterial
Immaterial additions do not void; repugnant to justice

precedents_cited.case_name: Bishop of Crediton v. Bishop of Exeter

precedents_cited.relevance: Special facts for bank note number

precedents_cited.case_name: Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corpn. v. Lo Lee Khi
precedents_cited.relevance: Alteration of bank note by erasure; still liable

statutes_cited.name: Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881
statutes_cited.relevance: Principle of material alteration; applies to negotiable instruments but wider principle for others; alteration carrying out intention immaterial

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Explanation 2: inadequacy of consideration does not avoid contract; past consideration supports guarantee

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed by majority (Kapur and Hidayatullah JJ.); suit against appellant guarantor upheld; no order as to costs (per Kapur J.)
outcome.relief_granted: Decree against appellant for guarantee up to Rs. 20,000/- upheld

key_quotes.text: "Now an unauthorised material alteration avoids a contract so that if a promisee after a written contract has been executed materially alters it without the consent of the promisor ... the contract is avoided"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: States general rule on material alteration (Kapur J.)

key_quotes.text: "if a guarantor entrusts a letter of guarantee to the principal borrower and the principal borrower makes an alteration without the assent of the guarantor then the Guarantor is liable because ... the principal debtor did will estop the guarantor"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Agency and estoppel principle applied (Kapur J.)

key_quotes.text: "The true rule ... is, that if there is any agreement between the principals ... the surety ought to be consulted, and that, if he has not consented to the alteration, although ... unsubstantial, or ... beneficial to the surety, the surety may not be discharged"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Law on surety discharge by alteration (Hidayatullah J. quoting Holme v. Brunskill)

key_quotes.text: "It must always be recollected ... A surety is bound ... to the letter of his engagement. ... If that written engagement is altered in a single line, ... my obligation ... is at an end."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Strict liability of surety (Hidayatullah J. quoting Blest v. Brown)
